name: Vitamin B3 (Niacin)
summary: Vitamin B3, also known as niacin, is an essential water-soluble vitamin important for energy metabolism, cardiovascular health, and skin integrity.
description: Niacin (Vitamin B3) exists in two main forms, nicotinic acid and nicotinamide (niacinamide). Both are precursors to nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD⁺/NADH) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP⁺/NADPH), essential coenzymes in cellular metabolism, DNA repair, and antioxidant defense. Niacin plays a key role in energy production, maintaining healthy skin, nerves, and digestion. High-dose niacin (nicotinic acid) has been used clinically to manage dyslipidemia, as it lowers LDL cholesterol and triglycerides while raising HDL cholesterol. Niacinamide is more often used in dermatology and supplementation, as it does not cause flushing. Deficiency results in pellagra, characterized by the “3 Ds”: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

metadata.natural_source: Meat, poultry, fish, nuts, legumes, whole grains, fortified cereals

primary_indications: Treatment and prevention of niacin deficiency (pellagra)
Adjunct therapy for dyslipidemia (high-dose nicotinic acid)
off_label_uses: Adjunct in certain psychiatric conditions (supporting NAD metabolism)
contraindications: Peptic ulcer disease (with high-dose nicotinic acid)
monitoring_required: Blood glucose (high doses may worsen insulin resistance)

items: Treatment and prevention of pellagra (niacin deficiency)
Adjunct therapy in dyslipidemia (high-dose nicotinic acid)

sections.text: Niacin is a precursor for NAD⁺/NADH and NADP⁺/NADPH, essential for cellular redox reactions, energy production, lipid metabolism, and DNA repair. High-dose nicotinic acid reduces hepatic VLDL synthesis, lowering LDL and triglycerides while raising HDL.

adult.typical: Oral dietary allowance: 14–16 mg/day; higher doses for deficiency treatment
adult.clinical: Dyslipidemia: 500–2000 mg/day (extended-release nicotinic acid, under supervision)

sections.pediatric: 2–16 mg/day depending on age; deficiency states may require higher doses under supervision

sections.text: Deficiency symptoms improve within days to weeks; lipid-lowering effects typically take weeks to months of consistent use.

other: High-dose niacin should only be used under medical supervision due to liver toxicity risk.
Niacinamide does not cause flushing but also lacks lipid-lowering effects.

items.risk: Increased risk of myopathy and liver injury

sections.pregnancy: Generally safe at dietary doses; high-dose niacin not recommended
sections.lactation: Safe at dietary doses; excreted in breast milk
sections.pediatrics: Safe at recommended dietary allowances; deficiency treatment requires supervision
sections.geriatrics: Safe but monitor liver and kidney function at higher doses

sections.text: Not required; however, discontinuation of high-dose niacin for dyslipidemia may cause rebound in cholesterol levels.

items: Niacin flush can be reduced by taking with food or aspirin 30 minutes before dosing.
Niacinamide is commonly used in skin care for anti-inflammatory and barrier-supporting effects.
Extended-release niacin formulations have lower flushing risk but higher risk of hepatotoxicity.
